p.content: Nominal phrases can be very complex. This section concentrates on the ordering of the modifiers which are written as independent words allowed in nominal phrases with common nouns as the lexical head. Modification by articles, demonstratives, possessors, quantifiers and degree words, adjective phrases, and
phrases is considered. Participles and gerunds are covered at the end of this section, but see section
for noun compounds whether or not they are written as a single word. Nominal phrases headed by proper names are discussed in section
and those headed by pronouns of all types and quantifiers are handled in sections
and
. Relative clauses, which normally come at the end of a nominal phrase, are covered in section
We begin with the modifiers which have the widest scope and then work in toward the noun.

section2.secTitle: Wide Scope Quantifiers and Degree Words

p.content: The wide scope quantifiers and degree words that modify the whole nominal phrase were discussed in section
The wide scope quantifiers and degree words that modify the whole nominal phrase, such as
, and
, were discussed in section
The following table reviews how the wide scope quantifiers and degree elements which modify the whole nominal phrase are expressed in
. The forms shown in the table are the roots; each one may surface with the appropriate classifier attached.
The following table reviews how the wide scope quantifiers and degree elements which modify the whole nominal phrase are expressed in
These elements are not expressed as independent words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase.
Some of these elements are not expressed as independent words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they attach to another word in the nominal phrase.

p.content: Negation of a nominal phrase also occurs in this wide scope position. See section
for examples.

In English, articles and demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, but they both occur before the noun. Some languages allow both to co-occur in the same phrase, and they may occur in different positions with respect to the noun. Therefore, they need distinct syntactic categories.
As seen in section

has only demonstratives that are realized as independent words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as independent words.

p.content: Possession can normally be expressed by a pronoun or by a nominal phrase which may consist of a proper name, a simple noun, or a fully modified noun.

Possession can normally be expressed by a pronoun or by a nominal phrase which may consist of a proper name, a simple noun, or a fully modified noun. However, Spanish only allows pronouns in the possessor position before the noun, with all noun and full nominal phrase possessors expressed in a prepositional phrase with
after the noun.
Within the languages which express possessors by nouns or full nominal phrases as well as by pronouns, many also add some kind of marking, such as the

in English, as an indication of possession. These markings are either affixes or clitics on the head noun or phrasal clitics which attach to one end of the whole phrase. Sometimes the possessor phrase marker is written as an independent word. The English marking is this second type, because alongside phrases where the
appears to attach to the head noun, as in
, there are phrases which clearly show that the clitic attaches to the end of the whole nominal phrase, such as
p.langData: the boy that I just talked to’s mother
p.content: or
p.langData: the girl in green’s wonderful speech
p.content: . These examples show that possessors can include
phrases and relative clauses. Possessors can also be embedded in one another, as in
. This is allowed in Spanish within the prepositional phrase after the noun.
In

case.caseText: both nominal phrases and pronouns may possess a noun directly, and both may also occur within a prepositional a postpositional an adpositional an adpositional phrase.
both nominal phrases and pronouns may possess a noun directly, but prepositional postpositional adpositional adpositional phrase possessors are not allowed.
only pronouns may possess a noun directly; nominal phrase possessors only occur within a prepositional a postpositional an adpositional an adpositional phrase.
neither nominal phrases nor pronouns may possess a noun directly; possession is only expressed within a prepositional a postpositional an adpositional an adpositional phrase.

phrase possessor occurs
the noun.

the noun.

the noun.

case.caseText: does not have any special marking to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the head noun within the possessor with an affix to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase. The affix is:
marks the whole phrase with a phrasal proclitic which attaches to the first word in the possessor to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase. The clitic is:
marks the whole phrase with a phrasal enclitic which attaches to the final word in the possessor to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase. The clitic is:
marks the whole possessor phrase with an independent word to distinguish it from any other nominal phrase. The presence of the marker word is optional in some cases. always required. It occurs

p.content: In English, possessors and articles or demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, unless the possessor is expressed in a prepositional phrase. For example,
is ungrammatical; instead one would use
to express the same thought. Some languages allow both possessors and articles or demonstratives to occur in the same phrase, so the first example above would be grammatical.
In
, nominal and/or pronominal possessors
occur in the same phrase as
in the normal possessor position

phrase.

p.content: Quantifier phrases include both numbers (section
) and the narrower scope quantifiers (section
Quantifier phrases include both numbers (section
) and the narrower scope quantifiers (section
). Such modifiers mark the number of the whole nominal phrase. English examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
and
p.langData: only the first one hundred boys
p.content: . All the quantifier phrases occur before the noun in English.

p.content: Qualitative adjectives and their modifiers were discussed earlier in section
Qualitative adjectives and their modifiers were discussed earlier in section
. Adjective phrases occur close to the noun, yielding nominal phrases such as:
p.langData: just those very few old, dirty books
all the boy’s many black dogs
p.content: and
p.langData: only the first one hundred very eager young boys
p.content: . As the English examples show, adjectives all occur before the noun, and, unlike the other modifiers discussed so far, more than one adjective phrase is allowed.
In
, adjective phrases occur

p.content: Both simple and compound nouns may have
phrase modifiers or complements.
Both simple and compound nouns may have
phrase modifiers or complements, such as in
and
. In addition, genitive
phrases may take the place of the possessor, such as
and
. In English, the prepositional phrase always comes after the noun.
In
, the
phrase occurs
the noun it is modifying.
examples with

for more details on
phrases in
Participles or participle phrases may act like qualitative adjectives modifying a noun.
Participles or participle phrases may act like qualitative adjectives modifying a noun. Some English examples with the participle or participle phrase bracketed include:
and
Examples in
include:
A gerund or gerund phrase may look like a noun and a complement. This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of an adposition.

A gerund or gerund phrase may look like a noun and a complement. This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of an adposition. Some English examples in full sentences with the gerund phrase bracketed include:
p.langData: [Studying participles] is challenging, He likes [reading Latin poetry]
p.content: and
p.langData: The receiver showed his worth by [making the catch].
p.content: Such phrases may be possessed or be modified as well, and sometimes only the gerund stands alone as the head of a nominal phrase, as in
and
Examples from
of gerunds or gerund phrases that can take the place of a nominal phrase include:
